Pinging you to point you towards [this comment](https://www.reddit.com/r/Silverbugs/comments/67le10/sigma_testers_are_not_perfect/dgstrkm/) I made to somewhat summarize the comments in the thread.

No, unfortunately it isn't. That being said, while the people here who are in favor of American hegemony and the supposed economic and political exceptionalism that allows us to do things like worldwide taxation (i.e. the people opposed to my view) are perfectly willing to reasonably discuss a million other issues, most of which I agree with them on, they aren't exactly willing to reasonably assume validity to other arguments either. There's extremists on both sides of every issue I'm afraid, and while one side definitely holds more blame than the other. The side **without** the orange baboon isn't perfect either.

Sure, it's going to be taxed in somewhere, and like most if not all corporate taxes, it's passed on to consumers (that's another issue though). There's definitely a discussion to be had though about the negative consequences of taxing corporations (and people, since dual residents and American ex-pats are taxed by us even if they have **zero** US derived income) this way.

This is actually one of the few things in his plan I can support. Do you realize that we are pretty much the **only country in the world** (bolded for emphasis) that does not use a territorial tax system? We don't have some great form of American exceptionalism that makes that make sense, not to mention making that morally or ethically defensible. No! We're just that arrogant and pig-headed that we think that because we're America, we deserve to tax income from companies and people who are, in the case of people often solely by birth, tied to this country when no other country claims that right.
Since I don't hold hope that our government, and more than a few people here who vehemently defend our system, will get its collective head out of its ass, tax holidays every once in awhile to at least incentivize companies bringing the money back in is the next best thing, since it'll still help our economy.

Hasn't evidence shown though that for the most part, the money gets blown by the descendants one or two generations down the line?
Some of the Rockefellers still have money of their own (not tied up in foundations and other restricted entities where they can't use the money for themselves), but the Vanderbilt's have lost most of their money, as have many if not most of the other robber-baron families. Unless there's some reason to thinking that these new-wealth families have some secret that these, arguably very smart, people didn't, they'll lose it all too given time and a few stupid heirs.
That's also not accounting for the actual utility of that money. A doctor making $250k in Des Moines is not the same as a doctor making 250k in San Francisco.

We created the AMT to ~~catch people trying to use loopholes to not pay their taxes~~ make up for the fact that our government is too stupid and corrupt to actually fix the tax code proper, so it catches people who otherwise would use too many of the loopholes they and their compatriots lobbied for to not pay any taxes.
FTFY

You'll still have gotten a bigger tax boost than us renters ever get, so you can go shove your deduction. The mortgage tax deduction is the biggest example of the government stupidly thinking that it can and should incentivize behavior with tax policy but they just end up screwing over large chunks of the population when they do. Fuck your tax deduction, may it be gone soon and never come back.

No more silly than the idea that there shouldn't be a legitimate discussion as to the government's role, if any, of using taxation to achieve social/societal goals, rather than for the original sole purpose of using taxation to raise revenue for the state.
There very much is an argument to be made that the government shouldn't be using, arguably misusing, tax policy as a form of social leverage to, in essence, blackmail people to do what the government wants. It is in fact IMO ethically and morally suspect for it to do so, especially since it is inherently and unequally picking winners and losers in the process (case in point, punishing renters with the homeowner tax credit).

For the most part, there is some other part to the transaction. Money is taxed when it is exchanged for something else, be it goods or labor. The one time other than inheritance where that isn't really the case is money earned on money without buying or selling an asset, such as for interest or dividends. Large gifts are also ostensibly taxable, but not necessarily actually taxed (in practice, not necessarily legally) if they're something non-monetary such as art.

That's a pretty broad definition of income you're trying to drive a logical truck through. A transfer of assets from one person to their descendant(s) is not income by the farthest stretch of the word. It was income when the first person earned it, but giving it a $5/10mil (single/married) exemption just cements the idea that the government isn't treating it as income on the transfer, but as an asset tax. That's is at least worth questioning since it is really the only federal asset tax (property, vehicle, and other such taxes being at city, county, or state levels).

The easiest and best way to do that would be to join the rest of the world in using territorial taxation (i.e. taxing only income earned in the US) for both people and corporations and the putting in place, and harshly enforcing massive penalties against any person or company trying to cheat by treating domestic income as foreign income, such as via transfer pricing for corporations.

Gawker was a bunch of assholes, and I agree that "news", with massive quotes is probably giving them too much credit, but it sets an incredibly bad precedent that someone with enough money can sue a company and a number of individuals into bankruptcy solely as a petty form of revenge. Maybe immature little bitch is a more appropriate thing to call him, since that was pretty much his reaction and he deserves to be mocked for it, regardless of what you think about Gawker. Not everyone who isn't left wing is a nazi and fascist, but nazis and fascists tend to be right wing. Totalitarian doesn't really make sense because he's a little ant. Crushing one company and a few poor excuses for webloggers using the courts isn't totalitarian, even if it does set a bad precedent. Now, if he had turned that into a campaign to pass a law saying you can't out gay republican billionaires, then that would be totalitarian.

To my knowledge, no we don't, and that is concerning. Erring on the side of caution though just means not getting the piece that tested as false, and if you're wrong then you've lost little. I'm more worried about the rate of false negatives (fake/plated pieces testing as real), since if the machine is wrong then, then you're probably out quite a bit of money. If there's an even more than infinitesimally tiny rate of false pieces testing as real, then that totally negates the purpose of having a tester.

IMO, there is enough real silver out there that if something reads as a fake, and the machine has a reasonably low rate of false positives, then it's not worth the risk to buy it. Unless it's a rare piece, otherwise something unique, or unless there's a good and knowable reason for the reading, then why risk losing good money on the hope that the machine is wrong?

Ars has a [newer story](https://arstechnica.com/security/2017/04/brickerbot-the-permanent-denial-of-service-botnet-is-back-with-a-vengeance/) (which I would have made the post, but it's on the sub's domain blacklist) which mentions that now it's up to Brickerbot 4.
I'll note that I have absolutely no interest in Radware, or any of the security companies listed in the Ars article, I just find this fascinating from both a technical and an ethical point of view.

You do realize that you don't have to keep it **in** your logbook, right? Much less show it to every CFI, FBO, or FAA inspector as they see fit. The suggestion is to keep it with or in your logbook so you don't lose it, but it's just stupid to believe that there is some mandate as to where you specifically have to put it.
You can and should tell any CFI or FBO who wants to see it to fuck off, and the FAA inspector can ask for it, but as the ASI above said, they don't care about anything except the certification by your doctor on the last page.

It isn't in that the doctor does not need to note normal/abnormal conditions and neither the pilot nor the doctor has any obligation to share it (in fact the doctor is probably prohibited from doing so per HIPAA) with the FAA or anyone else. If there's some sort of incident then the pilot would have to show it, and the doctor might be forced to show their copy, but otherwise it's a lot less onerous.

This seems no more risky for a doctor to sign than a camp physical form or a company physical. Arguably it's less risky, since nobody besides you and them (presumably the doctor will make and keep a copy for your file) sees it unless there's an incident, even to file and store it.

Assange isn't a whistleblower. Maybe whoever leaked information to him is, but he's not, to my knowledge, releasing information about wrongdoing in his organization. The idea of not prosecuting the Post or the Times for publishing the information is just de-facto practice, not policy or law, unlike protections for whistleblowers.

No, but when your entire body of work consists of sharing illegally obtained information (versus say the Washington Post or the New York Times which have shared illegally leaked/obtained information but that's the vast minority of what they do) then he's not going to get, nor does he deserve, much traction with that claim IMO.

While some protections apply to him if he's brought to the US, do you really think he would/will have a chance just by arguing a 1A right to receive stolen information and redistribute it? People are equating what he did to publishing it as a journalist, but there is a difference between Wikileaks and established journalism which should be pretty clear. The courts haven't caught up to expanding the definition yet, but even when they do, I can't imagine that Wikileaks, a platform exclusively designed for distributing illegally obtained/shared content, would even remotely qualify.

Those laws are also a good example of why populism is bad policy. Laws against price gouging, in general not necessarily in the case of a restricted market like pharmaceuticals, have been shown to reduce supply and slow the restoration of supply back into the area with an emergency occurred. The laws also encourage hoarding.
Again, doesn't really apply to those laws when they're (wrongly IMO) applied to something like pharmaceuticals which is already subject to a lot of supply restrictions among other things, but since you blindly mentioned price gouging laws, it should be pointed out that they at best don't work and at worst actually make problems worse.

All the more reason for the administration to be transparent about both the conditions and their reasoning behind these decisions. At this point, they aren't going to add to the controversy and they can give her critics/their supporters ammo to call her and her supporters on their bullshit.

It isn't just being postponed, there are serious conditions being placed on it. Again, maybe she just wants to be a martyr, but assuming she doesn't want to be killed or even injured by a mob, I'm somewhat inclined to trust Ann Coulter (never expected to use those three words in one sentence) when she says that the conditions are onerous. Hopefully if she or the University will release the conditions so we can really judge whether she's being oversensitive or whether these are truly harsh conditions that impinge on her ability to freely speak to the people who invited her.

Again, fine line balance. What the administration needs to do is create a viewpoint neutral (both in the the rules as written and in effect) set of rules for clubs when it comes to speakers. Controversial speakers, i.e. (in/at Berkeley, conservative speakers) should not and cannot be penalized for the fact that precious little liberal snowflakes don't want to let them speak and indeed don't recognize their right to speak (at least not without being shouted down/interrupted until they give up). In that same vein, no speaker, liberal or conservative, should be penalized for the fact that anarchists/rioters/and other pseudo-fascist elements from either or both sides, want to use these speeches as a platform to further their own ends, most of the time through use of violence.
That's where the line stands. You've crossed the line IMO the moment you start taking action that punishes the speaker, by restricting their right to speak or erecting extra barriers to their speech, solely based on the content of their speech or because of of the reaction of others to that speech. Incidentally, that's also the stance the Supreme Court has taken when it comes to the right to free speech an the right of speakers to not be silenced by the heckler's veto.

They're barely letting her speak. We don't know all the terms but they are by all accounts pretty onerous and we can assume that they're beyond what she feels she wants or needs. Maybe she's willing to be shouted down or even assaulted to serve as a martyr, but assuming she doesn't, then the University is actively hindering her speaking by trying to force a delay and these terms on her.
I'd agree that the school has an interest in ensuring safety, especially in circumstances like this, even, as you said, when they otherwise wouldn't be informed. That being said, there is a very fine line between giving in to a violent mob (on both sides of the political spectrum, since the far right wants a fight as much as the far left) and working to keep order in the venue while allowing her to speak and doing their best otherwise. If people want to hurt each other, they're gonna hurt each other, the University's goal should be to protect the speaker, school property, and any uninvolved members of the public that may be in the area. Likewise, City of Berkley PD should be worried about innocent people and city property, not what a bunch of douchebag anarchists and fascists do to each other when they're actively looking to start a fight/war. The focus here, on stopping these idiots from fighting seems way off, and totally unrealistic. There's no reason why the immediate goals, tied in to protecting her and letting her speak, can't be achieved though.

When they find one, let us know. Assange isn't a journalist and the ones he leaked the information to aren't being prosecuted. As much as calling him a "a non-state hostile intelligence service" is clearly baseless hyperbole, he definitely is something not well quantified by the established categories for things like this, and he's hostile to the US. Sharing information with publishers != publishing so he probably shouldn't get the same level of protection as a reporter, even if he would get some protections if he's brought to the US.

Protest can take place to try to stop the speech but the school has a moral, ethical, and probably legal duty to protect the speaker and do what they can to allow the speech to take place. The speaker is an invited guest of the school, by the fact that the school has dedicated the authority and the funds to the clubs to invite speakers that might interest the clubs to speak. The same isn't true of the protesters. The protesters of course can speak, but not necessarily in the same venue at the same time, and to the extent the rights clash, it seems pretty obvious that the invited speaker has a greater right to speak at the given time and place designated than the uninvited protestor. That's not to say the protestor can't protest/speak, just not in a disruptive manner then and there.

No, they really don't, and I'd be interested in you trying to find something to back that up. I'll save you the time and tell you that you won't find anything. That's your opinion, but you're wrong in this instance because as a public institution, the school itself, by allowing the clubs to pick speakers, doesn't get a right to veto speakers just because they may not be liked by people outside the club, doubly so if the club's discretionary funds (as in, at the discretion of the club to spend how they want within a given set of guidelines) are being used (which is what it seems like) to pay the speaking fees.

There's a legitimate question as to whether clubs usually notify the University higher-ups for speakers invited by the clubs though. If a club got a smaller name speaker and booked a space, would they be expected to get the OK from the school to do so beyond that? I don't know the answer for sure, but I would strongly suggest the answer is no. The University is in a no-win situation here because at best this is blatantly political, and at worst this is a double standard and cowardice because they have to give in the heckler's veto, mainly the threat of violence by anarchist fucktards (the violent mob, not to be confused with the people who want to, and need to have every chance to, peacefully protest this bitch).
